content:
The "Veterans' Justice Assurance Act of 2007" repeals term limits for judges of the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims. The "Veterans' Justice Assurance Act of 2007" eliminates term limits for judges of the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims. Judges shall hold office during good behavior, with exceptions for those serving on the date of enactment who have a 15-year term. A judge awaiting reappointment can continue for up to 1 year. SEC. 3. INCREASED SALARY FOR CHIEF JUDGE OF UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR VETERANS CLAIMS. The annual salary rate for a judge will be increased by $7,000 when serving as chief judge of the Court. SEC. 4. PROVISIONS RELATING TO RECALL OF RETIRED JUDGES OF THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR VETERANS CLAIMS. The amendment eliminates the limit on service of retired judges who voluntarily serve more than 90 days. It also states that retired judges recalled after retirement will receive pay of current judges only during periods of recall. The Veterans' Justice Assurance Act of 2007 allows judges who retire under certain conditions to receive retired pay based on their previous position, with exceptions for disability. The Veterans' Justice Assurance Act of 2007 allows judges who retire under specific conditions to receive retired pay based on their previous position, with exceptions for disability. If a judge did not provide notice of availability for service in a recalled status, their retired pay will be based on the rate at the time of retirement. For judges removed from recall status, their retired pay will be based on the pay at the time of removal. Pay during the period of recall is specified in section 7296(c)(1)(B) for recall-eligible retired judges. The Veterans' Justice Assurance Act of 2007 allows judges who retire under specific conditions to receive retired pay based on their previous position, with exceptions for disability. Pay during the period of recall for judges in recall status is determined by section 7296(c)(1)(B). Judges to whom section 7296(c)(1)(A) applies are paid at the rate of pay in effect for active judges, minus their annuity. Notice provided by a retired judge under section 7296(c)(1)(B) is irrevocable. The Veterans' Justice Assurance Act of 2007 allows judges to receive retired pay based on their previous position under specific conditions. Section 7296(c)(1)(B) determines pay for judges in recall status. Guidelines for recalling retired judges are established by the chief judge, considering factors like caseload and complexity. The judge must consult with specific organizations, the bar association of the Court, the Secretary, and other appropriate entities as determined by the chief judge. SEC. 5. Additional discretion in imposition of practice and registration fees. Amendments made to Section 7285(a) of title 38, United States Code, include inserting "reasonable" after "impose a" in the first and third sentences, and striking the limitation of not exceeding $30 per year in the second sentence.

SEC. 6. Annual reports on workload of United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims. The chief judge of the Court submits an annual report to Congress summarizing the workload, including appeals, petitions, applications, dispositions, time to disposition, oral arguments, and pending cases. The annual report to Congress by the chief judge of the Court includes a summary of petitions, applications, and service performed by recalled retired judges during the fiscal year. It also analyzes whether caseload guidelines were met. The term 'appropriate committees of Congress' refers to the Committee on Veterans' Affairs of the Senate and the Committee on Veterans' Affairs of the House of Representatives. The annual report to Congress by the chief judge of the Court includes a summary of petitions, applications, and service performed by recalled retired judges during the fiscal year. It also analyzes whether caseload guidelines were met. SEC. 7. REPORT ON EXPANSION OF FACILITIES FOR UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR VETERANS CLAIMS. The United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims is currently located in a commercial office building in the District of Columbia. In 2006, a feasibility analysis was provided for a dedicated Veterans Courthouse and Justice Center. In 2007, the Court suggested leasing additional space in the current location, which would require relocating other government tenants. The General Services Administration's 2006 feasibility report did not analyze the feasibility of locating a Veterans Courthouse and Justice Center at the current Court location. Congress believes the Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims should have suitable office space without causing disruption or cost to other Federal entities. The Administrator of General Services must submit a report within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Administrator of General Services must submit a report to the Senate and House Committees on Veterans' Affairs regarding the feasibility of leasing additional space for the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims and using the entire building as a Veterans Courthouse and Justice Center. The report should include an analysis of the impact on Federal tenants of the building used by the Court. The Administrator of General Services must submit a report to the Senate and House Committees on Veterans' Affairs regarding the feasibility of relocating Federal tenants to office space that offers similar or preferable cost, convenience, and usable square footage. If relocation is feasible and desirable, steps should be outlined to convert the building into a Veterans Courthouse and Justice Center, along with a timeline for the conversion. Federal tenants will have an opportunity to comment on the report before it is submitted. Before submitting the report to congressional committees, the Administrator must allow Federal tenants to comment on a draft of the report.
